values: This weekend: DOG SITTING!! Dad is outta town, so I offered to take care of dear sweet Bernard. We were up until 2 am last night trying to go to sleep- he was excited by his new surroundings. After three hours of sleep, we woke up again and went outside for a little walk. You can't ignore nature's call. Having Bernard here is a little adventure, since 1992 was the last time I had a dog in the house. Of course, I was only seven years old at the time and did not have to assume the responsibilities of the caretaker. Walking the dog, feeding him, disciplining him, etc, is a whole new ball game for me. And I'm loving every minute of it.

You gotta love people who don't like to eat anything colored, for example, buttercream frosting tinted pastel pink and pastel green. In my opinion, mint chocolate chip icecream that isn't green just isn't worth eating. On the flip side, I've never found anything colored/flavored blue raspberry particularly appetizing. Is there such a thing as a blue raspberry? 

Surely, the woman meant ARTIFICIAL color. I'm imagining a plate of only white food...potatoes, rice, cottage cheese, pasta, coconut flakes...feel free to add to the list

Today: no work, so I went shopping. It seems that Paris Hilton imposed her fashion sense on the designers for all of the clothing stores in the mall. Believe me, I'm one of the first people to wear something sparkly. But I don't want to dress like a peasant that's about to go clubbing every single day. Fortunately, I had pretty good luck in the boys department at Lord and Taylor- I needed polos like no otha. And I got some sweet board shorts.

Ok gotta split- dinner con mi padre. :-)

Well hey there!

I resume the livejournal. It took a backseat after a while (obviously).

If I decided to summarize soph year in detail, it would take me all week. Instead, I'm opting to just say that I enjoyed the good and survived the very, very bad.

This summer's employment is a major improvement from that of last summer. No more sitting at either:

A) a desk in a tiny room with no windows, the same 50 songs playing over and over again, and nothing to do but surf the web and maybe read.

B) a desk in a large room with lots of windows, the same 50 songs playing over and over again, and nothing to do but surg the web and maybe read. Oh yes, and a few interesting characters that spiced things up every now and then.

Instead, I'm working at the Baltimore Cupcake Company- this involved baking cupcakes, frosting cupcakes in pretty colors like pink, green, and yellow, selling cupcakes, and embarking on other little baking adventures, such as dipping fortune cookies in perwinkle tinted white chocolate. Sound sweet? It is. The hours fly by since I'm always occupied with kitchen duties- AND there are more interesting characters that come into the store that serve as one of many sources of entertainment.

Other summer plans: Saratoga Harp Colony for two weeks. This should be exciting, since I'll be studying with the principle harpist from the Philly Symph.

THANK GOD TOMORROW IS FRIDAY!!!!!!!!!!!!

 

And for your amusement: www.uglydress.com

By the way, that last entry was not written that early in the morning...the clock on my computer is confused and thinks that we live in California...silly silly.

The temperature was 50 degrees when I went outside this morning; in fact, I could see my breath as I walked to the gym.

Running on the treadmill and watching the sunrise (I work out early) causes little thoughts that I surpress in the speed of my daily life to surface. I began thinking of how people change....how certain little tendencies in people become more prominent as they grow older. Some unfortunately grow into their negative tendencies. Or perhaps that negative quality is only amplified because I know those somebodies on a deeper level....a level where that person feels free and comfortable enough around me to act as him or her true self. I don't know. My conscience says that I'm growing apart from those people...and this I cannot imagine. These people have shared amazing experince with me and have added a certain richness to my life. But then, I reflect on certain situations and realize that this opposite growth was all too evident. How could I have not seen it coming? Of course, part of maturing involves changes in friendships. I don't want that. I can see the potential in those relationships. They would have blossomed further had not those people matured as they did. I still need to hold on.....

Your love is... by ChibiMarronchan
Your name is...
Your kiss is...delicious
Your hugs are...warm
Your eyes...twinkle in the moonlight
Your touch is...irresistable
Your smell is...beautiful
Your smile is...hypnotising
Your love is...one of a kind
Quiz created with MemeGen!

So let's pick up where we left off.

I signed A Chi O. Now that I've been to 2 events at the house already, I know that I honestly could not be in a better sorority or have a better pledge class. Last night I went to the new pledge barbecue and sang karaoke- that's right, I said karaoke. I love karaoke...or shall i say, Caraoke (BOO). Anyway, I'm having a blast as a Greek.

**Sigh of relief and contentment:** Rush is over. I'm pledging. I am so proud to be an A Chi O..

Grab a date on Sunday...looking for someone to grab...hmm we'll see what happens.

Know how I said that I had a lot to accomplish at the end of that last entry? That was an understatement!

How can I best summarize what's been going down? Let's start with classes.....

Classes

I'm not terribly inspired by any of my classes this semester. Class Piano, so far, is simple and relaxing. Music Theory is....special. Sometimes I think that our teacher doesn't know what he's talking about. All the other classes have actually learned a great deal of new material, whereas we have maybe read one new chapter and have reviewed old stuff for the past two weeks. Music history wins the prize for Most Interesting Class. Lecture is lively and the reading is interesting (except when I'm tired and it's late at night). Orchestra has gone well, although the parts are building up. I desparately want to be prepared for this competition in April, but I don't know if that is going to happen....I'm trying to learn the music as quickly and efficiently as possibly. This is hard, however, when you're trying to learn three of the most difficult pieces in harp repertoire.

Greek

I came to school with the intention of rushing. I wasn't sure that I'd pledge...but I knew that if I never checked out the Greek System I would regret it. On Labor Day, my close friends and I went to 5 open houses. The day was intense- we socialized with complete strangers from 1 pm to 9 pm. My entire week revolved around open houses and invite parties. The next week, our emotions ran high while we all waited for invitations to Pref Parties. When it came closer and closer to final invite parties and then bid day, things became strained. For some people that I know who were positive that they wanted to go Greek, the whole rush process did not work out as they had anticipated. It seemed odd to me that I came in not even sure if I'd pledge. And yet, there I was, completely gung ho about joining a sorority and even living in the house. The Greeks that I favored were Alpha Chi Omega and Kappa Alpha Theta. Bid day came...and I got bids from both houses. The decision for me was so difficult....the Theta girls had been so active in courting me, and I had grown particularly close to one senior. My conversations with the girls that I had befriended over the past weeks at the Theta pref night really touched me...it had a lasting impression. They genuinely cared about me, and this was special. On the other hand, A Chi O felt like the house for me, and i knew that sympathies there were the same. As happy as I was to get bids from both, in a way I wished that I only had one bid so I wouldn't have to decide....I went with my first instincts and signed A Chi O. 

Ok, I'm dead tired, so I'm just gonna break here and pick up tomorrow, ya?

thanks.

Updates:

1) RHA

            I think that our freshmen programs this week were very successful, particularly the dance we sponsored on Saturday night. In fact, I've really enjoyed this whole week working with RHA, and am considering applying for an At Large position on the General Assembly if Greef Life doesn't appeal to me. Oh yeah, and I'm also thinking that if I do RHA instead of pledging, I'll be able to fit club swim team into my life.

2) Heat

You know its excrutiatingly hot when:

- I'm hot. I have a high tolerance for heat, and I get cold easily.

- You feel like your sweating even after you take a shower

- You change a few times a day because you just feel sticky and nasty.

- You can't sleep that well.

What stinks the most is that it's hotter in our room than it is outside. Last year, we never complained about this heat. I think maybe it's because the sun directly hits our room in Hagerstown, where we had some shade in Centreville.

I'll write more later...i got some stuff to accomplish

Know how you get on vacation and you lose track of what day it is?

Well, that's what happened to me. This is an indication that I have officially entered "College Park Bubble," a universe that is separate from that of the real world. We run on a separate time table here, I'm convinced. I can watch and read the news all I want...I still feel removed from the rest of society. Although I'm a current events junkie, this sense of seclusion is nice.

Since arriving in the Bubble, I've chilled with some of my friends who have moved in early and helped the RHA recruit new freshmen. I spent most of Wednesday making posters that advertise elections for Hall Council. Friday is the Carnival for the freshmen, and Saturday is a dance in the Union, which ought to be interesting since most people stay for about 10 minutes and leave.

Last night I went to this odd little place on route 1 that sells bubble tea. Bubble tea, in my opinion, is nasty...I can't do tapioca. I opted for some Hagen Daaz accross the street at Smoothie King. Mint Chocolate mmmm.....but how appropriate to go to the Bubble Tea restaurant while becoming acclimated to life in The Bubble?

I am one of the first people here!

I moved in today. It's a little hot, but I'm getting used to it. And I'm really tired.

This building is so nice compared to last year. The bathrooms are bright, the building isn't divided down the center, our room has a nice view (think NOT the farm) and we are in a prime location. I'm quite pleased.

After settling in, I went to go get dinner at the cafeteria, but alas, it closes at 6 for most of this week. I trekked over to Route 1 instead. I later went to work out at the CRC and watched family guy with a friend in Ellkton.

It's lovely being here, and I'm so sleepy that I really shoudl go to bed right now and write something later. Goodnight!

What if it became cool to use a baby carrier like a purse?

Ya know, it seems like everyone is getting pregnant- Adults in my world and Hollywood. Maternity stores have introduced more stylish clothing for moms-to-be. It's like pregnancy is a trend now.

I'm not really sure why I'm writing about this, it's just something that crossed my mind. I think it actually started when I was going into a restaurant the other day and saw this girl about my age carrying a baby in a carrier. The way she held the carrier startled me...she swung it around as if it was empty. I wanted to run up to her and remind her that she had a LIVE PERSON inside that massive, cumbersome plastic thing. So then, I got pictures developed from the xmas holiday (I'm horrible about having film developed). Several of them were of my aunt's and my cousin's wife's (I dont know what you'd call that relation..cousin in law?) babies. I go to those family functions and feel so left out. The ages are at complete opposite ends of the spectrum: Adults over the age of 38, and children under 3. Then, there is me: 18. Conversations involve babies: Taking care of babies, what the baby said the other day, lalalala. Don't get me wrong, here. I love children. I coached swim team for two years and wanted to take some of those kids home. Most importantly, I love my family. But it made me think, and then decide: I know that having children involves sacrifices, but it does not mean that I must remove myself from the Real World and permanently enter Baby Universe when I am a Mom. Not this seems so obvious, but when I think this over, I've really only interacted with new mothers in the past two years. Before that, the whole new parenthood thing was completely foreign. So am I redy for kids? Not yet, but I do have an idea of what names I like :-).

Friday was my last day of work. I couldn't get out of there FAST ENOUGH. Finishing at Tide Point- what a great way to kick off a weekend of fun.

From Friday evening to Sunday afternoon, I hung out in Ocean City with Aly, Sara, and Krisitin....we had a blast. It rained pretty much the whole time because of the hurricane, but fortunately we spent a little time on the beach on Saturday and Sunday morning. I got to ride some waves, which is ALWAYS a good thing.  Other than that, we shopped at all the surf stores on coastal highway, had icecream sundaes, watched the Olympics, played Spades and the 90s game, and ran around outside in the rain with our bathingsuits on.

So now its Monday...and in a week, I'll be back at school. This is so hard for me to believe... the summer flew by. I can't graspt the fact that a year has already passed. So much has happened, I've grown in so many ways. I hope that this year turns out for the best, particularly with my little "career conflict." We'll see what goes.

Rollin' with the tide......

<FONT color=#3333ff>Yesterday I took my car for a serious scrub down. But before that, I went to lunch with Marm. On our way home, I suggested that we stop by Trinity, my old Middle School, just for kicks. It's changed a great deal since I left there in '99. The nuns who owned the property sold much of it to Ryland Homes. Additionally, the building that I used for my classes from 5-8 grade is now used for administrative offices. The convent that stood on the hill was leveled, and a new middle school and cafeteria stand in its place. Anyway, we were driving up past the gym, when I noticed a bunch of old desks that "my generation used back in the day of Old Trinity" next to a dunpster, there for the taking. Obviously, I took one, and I made sure that it had tons of writing on the table top part. I took it to my room at Dad's house... I thought this might be nice, since he went to Trinity for elementary school and middle school. A few years ago, I gave him this wooden chair from the convent that he used when he was a boy. Now, I have a desk. Isn't it nice to take home some of your past?</FONT>

Check out this website: www.uglydress.com.

***********************************************************

"Channel Prep: Plum TV caputres the good life."

I never thought that someone would establish a television network for preppy people. "38 year-old wasp entrepreneur Tom Scott," the daddy of Plum TV, said that it will air in places like Nantucket, the Hamptons, Martha's Vineyard, Vail, Aspen, and Sun Valley. Programs will include everything from one act plays and documentaries, to  "life-style segments" and children's shows. J. Crew is obviously a major sponsor, since (a), it's one of the few major chain stores out there featuring pure preppy style (preps shop at independent boutiques and low profile chain stores), and (b), Scott's wife is J. Crew's founder. According to Scott, "We think it's sort of like Sundance, but for TV." And for Preppies. For more info on this, (although this is a great summary), check out the September issue of Vanity Fair.

*********************************************************

I love the Royal Farms on Key Highway. It's nothing fancy, just a massive quickie mart where you can also get gas.....but I associate it with so many good memories. I went there this morning to grab some coffee, which by the way, I rate as better-than-average. As usual, it smelled of baking doughnuts and music was blaring out into the parking lot (Bob Marley today). For some reason, I began to recall the first time I ever went there. It was on one of the many snow days we had during the winter of 2003. My mom and step-dad and I decided that we should go to the DSC to shovel some of the snow off the docks and boats. After laboring in the freezing cold for an hour, we decided to stop at the Royal Farms to warm up. This was all fine and dandy until our car wouldn't start. Oddly, we didn't worry, it was actually kind of funny. Some guy who had parked next to us gave us a hot shot. Then, we took a nice, long drive. This is just one of those nice memories of home you have...I don't know what makes it so comforting. I frequent that Royal Farms. It's  favorite place to stop before and after work. And although work has dominated, but has not been the highlight of my summer, thinking about all those times I stopped there for coffee at the crack of dawn, or for gas all dressed up and in a hurry to meet my friends, my work memories don't seem sooo bad. The humor of my gym-experience this summer is more prominent in my mind than the drudgery. A good way to finish off my job, since next week will be my last at Tide Point. :-)

Here are some work updates:

The music selection at Tide Point has improved greatly. It's no longer acid rock, thank god. It's more poppish, and I must admit, I do enjoy top 40. 

There is a pipe in the lost and found. And it's not the kind you use for tobacco.....I wonder if the person is going to ask for it. I hope I'm there for it if he/she does.

Hm that's about it for now. But we have a little less than three hours left, and anything is bound to happen in the crazy world of the fitness industry.

Dear God...this computer is from prehistoric times. A few minutes ago it randomly shut off, and then wouldn't turn back on. I decided to unplug and replug a few cords, and voila- it worked. 

As I'm sure you can guess, I'm back at woooork. I finish at this location in one hour, then I get an hour break, and then I go to the Fort Ave. location for six hours. 

Later on....

My vacation ended quite unexpectedly.

On Friday morning, we began having problems with one of the cars that we brought down. It wouldn't start. Long story short, we ended up having it toed to a near by garage that could replace the starter, and then picked it up that afternoon. We returned back to the condo late and decided to pack a few things and load one of the cars so we could avoid the morning rush. Unfortunately, when we went out to the car that had supposedly been fixed, it again wouldn't start. Great. It's midnight of the day we have to leave, and the car pooped out on us again. The only solution was to call AAA, get a hot shot and leave RIGHT THEN. That's what we ended up doing. I quickly packed the rest of my stuff, loaded the cars, and in two hours, AAA came, and we were on the road back to Baltimore.

So, now I'm home. I'm slowly unpacking and easing myself back into practicing. I feel like I never left....as though those two weeks were suspended in time. Fortunately, I'm going back to the beach this weekend for Aly's birthday, which of course will be an excellent time.

Until later....

Boo. Yay.

It's my last day at the beach, and its beautiful out. My feelings about leaving are ambivalent. I'm not ready to leave the "vacation mode," however, I am looking forward to shopping for school and coming back the beach next weekend with my friends. As I mentioned earlier, the Family occasionally becomes a bit grating. When I get home, I'll have a little more friend-time, so to speak.

I'm desparately hoping that this school year is not as stressful as last year. Part of the stress was my fault, but most of it resulted from the pressures of my major. Sometimes, I feel like that the Big-People-In-Charge in my dept. don't think that we have lives other than music. Their thoughts aren't completely false. I know some people who have only done music and never any other activity, still only do music, and only want to do music. I'm the complete opposite. Although I'm on a high level with my art,  I want to get involved in other communities at the University, specifically, the Greek community. I'm rushing the first week of school. It may end not not being my thing, but if I don't experiment, I know that I'll always wonder.

Yet again, when I compare my interests to that of my peers in my major, I begin questioning what career path is right for me. They have one interest, or their interest is so strong that it dominates everything else. I have diverse interests. I like being a "diverse person." I don't want to focus on ONE thing. I need to explore those other sides of who I am. I had a conversation with one of my music friends a long time ago. He told me that he had never considered a career in anything other than music. Interest in anything other than music did not exsist, and furthermore, there was no desire to explore anything other than music. To me, this was sad. In my opinion, there is so much in the world and in the mind of a single person. Why not explore every facet of who you are and your surroundings? My friend could have cared less. He was content with focusing on one area. Whatever floats your boat, I guess. I'm just confident that I'm not satisfied knowing only one part of myself.

Ever felt completely overwhelmed?

 Beginning last night, I began feeling a bit annoyed with my family. Not that I'm not having a nice time- it's been a lovely vacation. I am fortunate, in that I have relaxed parents and grandparents. Yet, I sometimes cannot help but feel the need for some alone time. I know that they haven't changed over the years. It's me who has changed.

I guess it really started last night. No one said anything offensive...I can't describe the feeling that began to build, but it was one of impatience. My tolerance for their idiosyncracies lowered. I woke up this morning in a bad mood, and tried my best to cover it. It finally hit its peak today, when we were having a benign conversation on the beach about plans for the fall. I got up, and said, "I'll be back," and began walking down the beach. After about 15 minutes, I felt centered again, so I turned back.

Everything has been fine since then...I only wish I could identify the thing that triggered that sour mood. I know that I haven't changed for the worse. As my Mom joked when I returned from first year at college, "She turned out real nice, didn't she?" My family hasn't been smothering, either. They've done well giving me my own space this summer. I guess that everyone goes through a period of growth where their family becomes slightly grating.

Sorry about this terribly directionless, open ended entry. I had to vent. Thanks.

Dork. Geek. Nerd. Do these all mean the same thing or is there a difference between the three? Could someone please explain?

I bet you're wondering what could have possibly provoked this question. Observe the following terms/statements:

1) "Dorchestra," pronounced Dork-estra. It pertains to the dorks in orchestra, in case you couldnt figure that one out.

2) "I'm a huge Band Geek." I was never in band. Rather, I was and am in dorchestra.

3) "You're a nerd." This has been said to me on a few occasions, and is often followed by, "over-achiever." Is over-achiever synonomous with nerddom?

Time for bed.

Peeeeewww: we had a stinky beach today.

It rained yet again, and then stopped. Unfortunately, the sun never came out. I still went to the beach- I thought it might be nice to get in the ocean, and maybe take a run. When I got down by the water, I found dead fish strewn all over the shore. They were completely in tact, no cuts or anything, and were about 10 inches long...and smelled just as rank as it looked. In fact, the odor completely permeated the beach air. According to the life guard, a sudden change in the water temperature (which, I assume resulted from Alex) caused a major fish kill.  I whipped out my surgical gloves, picked some of those dead suckers up, started a bonfire and had a huge seafood feast. Syke. I practically gagged when I saw those things lying there on the sand. Bluhgh.

YES! The Sun has made an appearance!!!!! Tomorrow should be great.....

Ahhh Hurricane Alex.

This morning was disgusting, but those clouds burned off around 11 am and we had sunshine! After missing a day of beach, today meant serious surf time. Of course, because there is a storm off the coast, there was a bit of a current, but that's what I look for- you'll have beautiful waves for the most part. Later, however, it became a little choppy and unpredictable (not that the ocean is predictable to begin with, but, ya get my gist). Ew, and there were dead fish floating around....tasty. Oddly enough, I feel much better after spending the day in the water. My cold seems like its almost gone, but I'm going to continue being careful and monitoring my throat.

Time to get ready for another evening out!


**HAPPY BIRTHDAY, ALY.

Woo I switched to live journal! Why, you ask? Perhaps the reasons that are trivial, but here they are:

1) I can personalize it more than I can the xanga

2) It has more features, like adding links to your friends' journals (which I have yet to do)

Just to give a little intro.... This journal will not disclose anything terribly personal. Its entires are just updates on what's generally going on in my life, interpersed with the random thoughts that float around in my mind.

 

Oh yeah, I'm the one on the far right.
